title: Cabinet signals controlling migration to take precedence over single market access in Brexit talks - Politics live | Politics | The Guardian
summary: no 10 's readout from the chequers cabinet meeting .
corbyn proposes 'gender audit ' of labour policies .
guardian/icm poll gives tories 14-point lead over labour .
yougov 's labour leadership poll - 10 findings from the small print .
theresa may tells cabinet there will be no second referendum and no 'back door ' attempts to stay in eu .

documents.title: afternoon summary
text: downing street has signalled that controlling immigration will take precedence over retaining access to the single market in the brexit talks .
see the update at the bottom of this post for more details .
number 10 has said the government is committed to ensuring britain remains one of the great trading nations in the world '' when it leaves the eu .
( see 4.14pm . )
labour has warned theresa may that the uk must hurry up and ratify the paris climate deal before the year is out or risk being sidelined in influencing future action on global warming .
jk rowling , the harry potter author and labour supporter , has urged jeremy corbyn 's supporters to stop comparing him to dumbledore .
she made the comment in one of many anti-corbyn tweets she posted today .
j.k. rowling ( @ jk rowling ) corbyn .
is .
not .
dumbledore .
the ryanair boss michael o'leary has said he expects brexit to cost the no-frills airline 5 million passengers next year , as he predicted the uk would end up looking pretty stupid '' .
that 's all from me for today .
thanks for the comments .
update : a spokesperson for the prime minister has issued a statement about what was discussed at the political cabinet - the phase of today 's cabinet meeting set aside for party political matters .
the spokesperson said : the prime minister chaired political cabinet at chequers this afternoon .
the meeting began with a discussion led by patrick mcloughlin .
he spoke about the strength of the conservative party , with membership growing by almost 50,000 over the summer .
looking ahead to conference he announced the largest attendance in over a decade and that the theme would be a country that works for everyone '' .
the prime minister added this reflected the fact that we are a united party and a united government , getting on with the job of delivering on the issues that british people care about .
this was contrasted with the inward looking and divided opposition .
it was agreed that the opening day of conference would be about global britain - showing that we are more outward looking than ever before .
in a discussion about brexit the pm said that there were two related imperatives : getting the best deal for people at home , and getting the right deal for britain abroad .
there was a strong emphasis on pushing ahead to article 50 to lead britain successfully out of the european union - with no need for a parliamentary vote .

furthermore , several cabinet members made it clear that we are leaving the eu but not leaving europe , with a decisive view that the model we are seeking is one unique to the united kingdom and not an off the shelf solution .
this must mean controls on the numbers of people who come to britain from europe but also a positive outcome for those who wish to trade goods and services .

on the agenda and discussed at length was the commitment to the devolved nations to make sure that brexit works for all - but cabinet members were clear that it is the united kingdom 's government 's decision to establish its terms and on when to trigger article 50 .
and here are the key points .
the cabinet has agreed that getting a brexit deal that will allow the uk to control immigration will take precedence over getting a deal that gives full access to the single market .

that is the implication of the statement that the deal must mean controls on the numbers of people who come to britain from europe but also a positive outcome for those who wish to trade goods and services . ''
the word controls '' is specific ; the phrase positive outcome '' is vague , and could mean very little .
mps will not get a vote on the decision to invoke article 50 , triggering the formal two-year eu withdrawal process , the cabinet has confirmed .
scotland , wales and northern ireland will be consulted over brexit , but will not get a veto , the cabinet has confirmed .
theresa may addressing cabinet at chequers .
rousseau/afp/getty images
i 'm told there was more said about brexit at the political cabinet .
we 're expecting to get some more briefing on that shortly .
so my previous post ( see 4.14pm ) may have been premature .

documents.title: no 10 's readout from the chequers cabinet meeting
text: number 10 has just released a readout from today 's cabinet meeting at chequers .
this is from the prime minister 's spokeswoman .
the prime minister chaired cabinet at chequers this morning .
after the usual update from the leaders of the commons and the lords on parliamentary business , the discussion moved on to the economy .
the chancellor provided cabinet colleagues with an update on the economic outlook .
the cabinet reiterated the government 's commitment to fiscal discipline and living within our means .

ministers agreed that we should be seizing the opportunity of brexit to confirm the uk 's place as one of the great trading nations in the world , fostering entrepreneurialism and setting out a long term vision for the country .
they also agreed on the vital need to increase productivity and the importance of doing more to foster economic growth and industrial development in regions up and down the country .
the foreign secretary then provided an update on the campaign to defeat daesh in syria , iraq and libya and the uk 's role in supporting political progress in all three countries .

the foreign secretary highlighted the progress that had been made in squeezing the territory held by daesh , with 40 % reclaimed , as well as a fall in support for daesh 's ideology around the world .

the cabinet agreed that islamist terrorism continues to be one of the greatest security threats we face and therefore we must continue to work closely with our allies to defeat daesh and to support strong , stable governance in countries around the world , particularly in countries where terrorists are trying to establish safe havens .
conversations continued after lunch during a meeting of the political cabinet .
this morning , in her opening remarks , theresa may said cabinet would discuss the next steps '' to be taken in relation to brexit .
but this statement says very little about this , beyond saying the government wants britain to remain one of the great trading nations in the world '' .

at this stage ( i have not had any further briefing yet ) it is not clear whether that is because ministers did not agree anything meaningful on the next stage of brexit , or whether they did but are just choosing to keep it all secret .
may says brexit means brexit '' but that 's just circular logic .
as for what it really means , that remains as much of a mystery as ever .

documents.title: corbyn proposes 'gender audit ' of labour policies
text: at an event at unison hq later this afternoon jeremy corbyn will be announcing proposals to benefit women .
his team have just emailed out the details .

his plans include having a regular gender audit '' of labour policies , setting up a new women 's advisory board to advise the leader and toughening the law ( in a manner so far unspecified ) on online harrassment .
here are the key announcements from the news release .

increasing women 's representation in our society , democracy and party by supporting all women shortlists to achieve 50:50 representation in parliament and the same aim for all public offices ; supporting a policy-making annual labour women 's conference ; publishing a regular 'gender audit ' of labour policies ; and consult on establishing a high level , strategic women 's advisory board linked to the leader 's office to ensure women are at the heart of our policies , and to support the shadow secretary of state for women and equalities , along with advisory boards on other equality strands .
investing in an economy that delivers for women .
austerity is n't working and has disproportionately harmed women .

our public investment strategy will provide a foundation for the economy to grow , and from which to properly fund and democratise our public services and end the cuts that women , as the majority of public service users and workforce , have borne the brunt of .
labour will ensure increased recruitment of women into science , technology , engineering and manufacturing occupations and will tackle occupational segregation in our economy .

labour will also give enhanced powers to the equality and human rights commission to penalise companies that do not publish detailed gender pay data at a company-wide level as part of tackling equal pay issues .

tackling sexual harassment and threats online through a wide-ranging consultation exercise on how to strengthen the law and its implementation and increase organisations ' responsibility towards promoting safe and respectful 'community standards ' online .

within the party we will take forward the recommendations of the shami chakrabarti inquiry to consult on and introduce a wider equal opportunities policy , training and guidance for members and staff , recognising that online abuse is often also racist and homophobic in nature as well as misogynistic .

some of these proposals ( for example , on equal pay audits ) are similar or identical to what corbyn proposed in his working with women policy paper ( pdf ) in last year 's leadership contest , but in some respects corbyn is now going further .
for example , last year he spoke of wanting to ensure 50 % of labour mps were women .
now he is talking of aiming to get 50/50 male/female representation for all public offices '' .
on the world at one jacob rees-mogg , the conservative backbencher , explained why hardline brexiteers like himself were opposed to britain remaining in the single market .
i think the expectation or desire to remain in the single market is basically code for rejecting the referendum result .

the single market is the engine room of eu regulation ; it 's the requirement for free movement of people that comes with it that has put people off the european union , and so i think any effort to keep us within the single market is basically rejecting the referendum result .

he also dismissed claims that the government would have difficulty deciding brexit policy because the three leading brexit ministers - boris johnson , the foreign secretary , david davis , the brexit secretary , and liam fox , the international trade secretary - do not get on .
it would be fine , he suggested , because they were all affable personalities '' .
they 're three strong but enormously affable personalities .

i think if you were to give a dinner party and you had boris johnson , david davis and liam fox you would be guaranteed an entertaining evening because they are people of great character , strength of character , and good company .
damian mcbride , gordon brown 's former spin doctor , says he is surprised that theresa may was allowed to let a tv camera film her opening remarks to cabinet at chequers .
damian mcbride ( @ dpmcbride ) since when is filming of meetings or interviews allowed at chequers ?
we were always told it was strictly forbidden :

documents.title: lunchtime summary
text: theresa may has told her cabinet that there will be no attempts to stay in the eu by the back door '' , as she began the first meeting of her top team since the summer break .
a yougov poll for the times suggests that jeremy corbyn is on course to win the labour leadership with an even bigger majority .
( see 9.02am . )
an icm poll for the guardian gives the tories a 14-point lead over labour .
( see 1.12pm . )
tim farron , the lib dem leader , has accused both sides in the eu referendum campaign of lying to voters .
in a speech to the ippr thinktank in manchester he said : never in recent history have we , in the political classes , let down the people of this country so disastrously .
and i make no distinction here between those who voted to remain and those who voted to leave .
they were battered with dodgy statistics .
from both sides .
they were lied to .
on both sides too - though it is the nhs and the £ 350 million that particularly sticks in the throat .
and worse than that .
they were misled by lackadaisical politicians , playing games , who had campaigned for years to leave the eu - but had n't bothered to come up with a plan about what to do if it happened .
he also said that racists '' should not be allowed to hijack the result .
because of those divisions , we are in danger of letting malevolent forces hijack the result .

plenty of my mates voted leave and i can tell you that the majority of those who did vote leave are utterly appalled that farage , le pen and their ilk now seek to claim the result as a victory for their hateful brand of intolerance , racism and insularity .
britain is better than that .
owen smith , the labour leadership contender , has said he would not oppose another scottish independence referendum .
in an interview with bbc radio scotland , he said that there there should not be another referendum but that it is a matter for the scottish people .

the uk 's social security system is rapidly becoming unfit for purpose , as successive cuts leave children and working age adults with an increasingly inadequate safety net for when families fall on hard times , according to a study .

as patrick butler reports , most low-income working households will be worse off by 2020 , while years of social security squeezes mean the income of families on out-of-work benefits will have fallen by up to one-fifth , the analysis by the fabian society shows .
junior doctors are pushing for monthly five-day strikes to be held between now and the end of the year in an escalation of the dispute over their new contract , according to leaked documents .
( if you appreciate this blog , or guardian journalism generally , please consider becoming a guardian supporter .
we publish our reporting for free online , but it is not free to produce and , with the newspaper industry in financial crisis , frankly we need every penny we can get .
being a supporter costs £ 5 a month and you would be helping to sustain progressive , public interest journalism .

there is nothing inevitable about news organisations surviving and , if the guardian were to go bust , there would be no politics live and , the next time a big political story was breaking , you would be stuck with twitter . )

documents.title: guardian/icm poll gives tories 14-point lead over labour
text: the guardian has released its latest icm poll .
as anushka asthana reports in her splash story , it gives the tories a 14-point lead .
the cabinet meeting comes as a new icm/guardian poll gives the conservatives a 14-point lead over the opposition , with may 's party up one point to 41 % , while labour has fallen one point to 27 % .
here are the full figures .

conservatives - 41 % ( down 2 points from icm last month ) labour - 27 % ( no change ) ukip - 13 % ( no change ) lib dems - 9 % ( up 1 ) greens - 4 % ( no change ) icm collected responses from 1,813 people between 26 and 28 august .
here 's a press association photograph from today 's cabinet .
theresa may holds a cabinet meeting at chequers .
pool/getty images
before theresa may starting chairing cabinet she spoke to two fellow european leaders , the finnish prime minister juha sipilä and the norwegian prime minister erna solberg .
they both congratulated her on becoming prime minister .
according to number 10 , may told them both that brexit would not mean the uk turning its back on europe .

a downing street spokesman said : in the discussions the prime minister said that though the uk is leaving the eu we are not turning our back on europe and want to maintain a good relationship with the eu as well as individual european countries .

the prime minister explained that the uk will not trigger article 50 before the end of the year to give the uk and the eu time to prepare for negotiations and to help ensure that the process is as smooth as possible .

the pm added that as we embark on those discussions , we should consider what is going to work best for the uk and what is going to work for the european union , rather than necessarily pursuing an existing model .
the prime minister also said that , while the uk remains a member of the eu , we will play a full role , live up to our obligations and remain a strong supporter of free trade .
on defence and security the prime minister said that the uk will remain an outward facing and globally engaged nation , including through our membership of nato .

i have added an update to the 10 findings from the yougov poll '' post at 11.04am to address some of the objections readers have raised to my account of what it says about corbyn supporters being more likely to join a new party if they do n't get the leader they want ( point 7 ) .
news has broadcast some footage of theresa may delivering her opening remarks to cabinet .
you can watch it here , starting at 11.30am .

the main point of interest is boris johnson , the foreign secretary , who is sitting at may 's right and who starts off nodding judiciously at her words , before staring into the distance towards the end as if he 's getting bored .

you can also just about hear him come out with a half-hearted cheer ( more like a 'yurggh ' ) as may says there must be no attempts to stay in the eu by the back door ( even though this was a strategy johnson himself seemed to be backing last year . )
may seemed to be speaking off the cuff , rather than from notes .
that perhaps explains her comment about not staying in the eu by the back door .
as a colleague points out , you can leave or enter a building by the back door , but not stay in it .
theresa may addressing cabinet .
news/theresa may addressing cabinet theresa may addressing cabinet .
news theresa may addressing cabinet .
news/bb theresa may addressing cabinet .
news

documents.title: theresa may tells cabinet there will be no second referendum and no 'back door ' attempts to stay in eu
text: number 10 has just released the text of the statement that theresa may made as she opened this morning 's cabinet meeting at chequers .
here are the key points .
may ruled out a second referendum on brexit , and insisted that there would be no attempts to sort of stay in the eu by the back door '' .
we must continue to be very clear that brexit means brexit '' , that we 're going to make a success of it .
that means there 's no second referendum ; no attempts to sort of stay in the eu by the back door ; that we 're actually going to deliver on this .
she said britain was at a very significant '' turning point and that it could play a new positive role '' in the world .
can i just remind everybody that this really is a very significant moment for the country , as we look ahead to the next steps that we need to take .

we have the opportunity to forge a new positive role for the uk in the world ; to make sure that we are that government and country that works for everyone - that everyone can share in the country 's prosperity .
she stressed her commitment to leading a one nation government and ensuring that everyone can share in the country 's prosperity '' .
she said the cabinet meeting would discuss social reform , the economy and future legislation as well as brexit .
this reinforces the point that may made at her first cabinet meeting about not wanting her government to be defined by brexit .
she reaffirmed her intention to get tough on irresponsible behaviour in big business '' .
and here is the full text of may 's remarks .
thank you very much for coming together today .
it 's our first opportunity to meet since the summer recess , but also the first opportunity for us to meet since the fantastic success of the gb team at the olym - absolutely great .
and also the paralym will be starting very soon , so we wish our paralympic athletes all the very best and success there as well .
but obviously over the summer - over the last few weeks - quite a lot of work has been done .
we 're going to be having an opportunity today to discuss this .

we will have an update on brexit ; we 'll be looking at the next steps that we need to take , and we 'll also be looking at the opportunities that are now open to us as we forge a new role for the uk in the world .
we must continue to be very clear that brexit means brexit '' , that we 're going to make a success of it .
that means there 's no second referendum ; no attempts to sort of stay in the eu by the back door ; that we 're actually going to deliver on this .
we 're also going to talk this morning about social reform .
we want to be a government and a country that works for everyone , and we 'll be talking about some of the steps that we need to take in order to build that society that works for everyone .
and i want it to be a society where it 's the talent that you have and how hard you 're prepared to work that determines how you get on , rather than your background .
we 'll be having an update on the state of the economy .
we 'll be looking at how we can work to increase productivity - that 's one of the key issues that we want to address .
but also how we can get tough on irresponsible behaviour in big business - again making sure that actually everyone is able to share in the country 's prosperity .
we will be looking at the legislative programme that we have coming up in parliament .
and we 'll also be hearing a political update from the party chairman , particularly as we look forward to our party conference .
so quite a packed agenda for our meeting today .
but can i just remind everybody that this really is a very significant moment for the country , as we look ahead to the next steps that we need to take .

we have the opportunity to forge a new positive role for the uk in the world ; to make sure that we are that government and country that works for everyone - that everyone can share in the country 's prosperity .

so there are challenges ahead but it 's an important and significant moment for us and i think we have real opportunities to develop the united kingdom and ensure that it does work for everyone in the uk .

documents.title: yougov 's labour leadership poll - 10 findings from the small print
text: as promised , here is more from the detail of the yougov poll .
i posted the key findings at 9.02am .
here are 10 more findings from the survey .
1 - corbyn 's key strength is that he is seen as principled '' .
some 76 % of the labour selectorate said they saw him this way .
he also scored well for honesty ( 64 % ) and for shares my political outlook '' 58 % .
but only 33 % of the labour selectorate as a whole said he was likely to lead the party to victory at the election , and only 35 % said he was competent .
this is from the new statesman 's stephen bush .
stephen bush ( @ stephenkb ) hard to sustain from these numbers that labour members are `` mad '' or in denial about corbyn 's failings .

people planning to vote for corbyn in the contest were more likely to rate his competence and electability , but even amongst this group only 56 % said he was likely to lead the party to victory , and only 60 % said he was competent .
2 - smith 's key strength is that he is seen as competent '' .
but only 30 % of the labour selectorate said they saw him as competent - a remarkably low figure , given that he has put this trait at the centre of his leadership campaign .
his biggest weakness is that he is seen as untrustworthy '' - by 45 % of those voting in the contest .
3 - smith is seen as even less likely than corbyn to lead labour to victory at the general election by those voting in the contest .
only 12 % of them said they thought smith was likely to win the general election for the party .
and even amongst those planning to vote for smith the figure was only 33 % .
4 - women seem to be more pro-corbyn than men .
the yougov crosstabs have 67 % of female members of the labour selectorate backing corbyn , but only 57 % of men .
crosstab findings are less reliable than the headline poll findings ( because they involve a smaller sample ) , but a 10-point gap is quite big , and so some gender gap is probably real .
during the campaign smith has been accused of sexism , and corbyn 's advantage with women may be a result .
5 - corbyn 's support is broadly consistent amongst all age groups .
it is often assumed that his backing comes from the young .
but the crosstabs ( in so far as they are reliable - see above ) suggest age is not a factor in his support .
his ratings are 61 % amongst 18 to 24-year-olds , 64 % amongst 25 to 39-year-olds , 63 % amongst 40 to 59-year-olds and 57 % amongst over-60s .
6 - a majority of labour members are in favour of getting rid of the nuclear deterrent .
some 53 % of those voting in the leadership contest , and 52 % of those voting because they are full party members , think britain should get rid of nuclear missiles .
only 23 % of party members favour full trident renewal , while another 14 % of members favour replacing the trident submarines but not equipping them with nuclear missiles .
these figures suggest corbyn , who is in favour of nuclear disarmament , would be able to win a vote on trident if he put it to a ballot of party members .
but this would involve bypassing the normal policy-making procedure , a vote at party conference .
corbyn would find it much harder to win a conference vote on this because unions have 50 % of the vote at conference and the big unions are pro-trident because they want to preserve defence jobs .
7 - corbyn 's supporters are more likely to leave the labour party if they do not get the leader they want than smith 's .
corbyn 's supporters sometimes accuse their opponents of wanting to split the party ( john mcdonnell has said this explicitly . )
but the yougov poll suggests the corbynistas would be more likely to walk away .
asked what would happen if corbyn won , and his opponents formed a rival party , 18 % of members said they would leave and join it .
but when asked what would happen if smith won , and his opponents formed a rival party , 32 % of members said they would leave and join it .
update : on twitter and perhaps btl ( i have't read comments yet ) readers have challenged this on a couple of grounds .
first , genie research points out that , given there are almost twice as many corbyn backers as smith backers , it is not surprising that corbyn backers seem more included to split .
genie research ( @ genieresearch ) @ andrewsparrow maths is wrong on 7/10 : corbynite propensity to leave = 32/62 = 52 % ; smithite ptl = 18/38 = 47 % .
a very small gap - half each the crosstabs present slightly different figures .
amongst those planning to vote corbyn , 54 % would join a new party if they did not get the leadership result they wanted .
amongst smith supporters , the figure is 45 % .
so there is a difference - but it is not a big one .

second , some readers think the first sentence in paragraph 7 is misleading because the yougov questions were based on the assumption that mps might split and form a new party , and arguably it is the anti-corbynites in the plp who are most likely to do this .
it is certainly true that no pro-corbyn mps have been talking about forming a new party if corbyn loses .
but anti-corbyn mps do not seem to be seriously talking about a new party either .
there are reports that some of them are considering setting up a new gropu in parliament .
but launching an entirely new party would be hugely problematic , and i am not aware of any mp advocating this .
what is true is that some people who used to support other parties ( eg , the greens , tusc ) have joined labour because they like corbyn .
it is easy to see them leaving if he were replaced - although that is not the same as them defecting to form a new party .
8 - more than a third of those voting in the contest ( 39 % ) think it is likely the labour will split when it is over .
9 - almost half of those voting in the contest ( 48 % ) think labour mps should be subjected to mandatory reselection .
10 - the traingate controversy damaged corbyn 's standing in the contest - but not by much .
some 20 % of those voting in the contest said they had a more negative view of him as a result of it , against 10 % who said they had a more positive view of him as a result .
almost 70 % said it had no effect on their thinking .
as i said earlier ( see 9.02am ) yougov 's record last year suggests this poll is likely to be a reasonably reliable guide to the eventual outcome .
but in his own write-up of the survey , yougov 's matthew smith says it is important to remember the various factors that could lead to the final result being different .
there are a number of important caveats that should be highlighted .

our survey sample is composed of 1,236 members of the labour selectorate , with the representation levels of difference membership types ( member/supporter/union affiliate ) based on how each group turned out in the 2015 leadership election .

changes in turnout have the potential to affect the results : this is particularly true of trade union affiliates ( amongst whom turnout was low in 2015 ) given that the gmb is under new leadership and has come out for smith this time round .
the make-up of registered supporters is also difficult to judge , whilst the effects and scale of labour party membership suspensions also has the potential to make a difference .
last , but not least , there are still three weeks left to vote , and unforeseen events could drastically affect the course of the contest .
nevertheless , team corbyn will be pleased by the security afforded by the double digit lead they are currently sitting on .

anna soubry , the conservative former business minister and an opponent of brexit , was on the today programme this morning being interviewed ahead of today 's cabinet meeting at chequers ( which she is not attending , obviously . )
she said the government 's brexit deal should ensure britain keeps access to the single market and free movement of people .
i am concerned though about any plans to curb immigration i believe in the free movement of labour from the eu .
it has benefited our country , especially business .
theresa may and her ministers have said very little about what their negotiating priorities will be , although what they have said suggests soubry will not get her way .
may has suggested that taking control of immigration will be a priority , even if that results in britain not being able to remain a full member of the single market .
( two weeks ago itv 's robert peston wrote a revealing facebook post about the government 's brexit thinking .
peston did not disclose his sources , but it read as if it were based on a briefing from someone in david davis 's brexit department .
peston said the government was examining the case for a canada-plus free trade deal with the eu . )
lord lawson , the pro-brexit conservative former chancellor , was also on the programme .

he said that britain should not waste time trying to negotiate elaborately '' a special trade deal with the eu and that article 50 , which starts the formal two-year withdrawal process , should be triggered as quickly as possible .

the polling company yougov has a huge panel of of people who participate in its online polls and , because it knows which of them belong to political parties , it finds it relatively easy to carry out party membership polls .
it polled labour members during the leadership contest last summer and its findings were a reliable guide to the final result .

( a poll in august had jeremy corbyn on 53 % of first preference votes , more than 30 points ahead of his nearest rival , andy burnham ; a month later corbyn won with 59 % of first preference votes , 40 points ahead of burnham . )
and so , on the basis of today 's times spash , corbyn would be entitled to conclude that he is home and dry .
the times reports the findings of yougov 's latest labour membership poll .
and they suggest corbyn is on course to win by an even bigger margin than he did last year .

nick sutton ( @ suttonnick ) wednesday 's times front page : corbyn on course to win bigger mandate # tomorrowspaperstoday # bbcpapers yougov ( @ yougov ) new yougov/times labour leadership poll of the party selectorate : corbyn 62 % , smith 38 % yougov ( @ yougov ) labour leadership poll : corbyn leads among each part of the selectorate the poll suggests owen smith , corbyn 's challenger , would win if the electorate were restricted to people who joined the party before the 2015 election .
but corbyn is well ahead with new members , and also has a huge lead amongst those entitled to vote because they have paid £ 25 to become registered supporters .
corbyn also leads smith amongst union members who can vote as affiliates , the third group of voters in the contest .
here 's an extract from the times ' story ( paywall ) .
among those who joined before may last year , support for mr smith is at 68 per cent compared with 32 per cent for mr corbyn , according to the yougov poll .

it drops to 28 per cent for mr smith among those who joined between may and september , and to 14 per cent for those who signed up after september , underlining mr corbyn 's popularity among newer members .
a further 129,000 paid a one-off £ 25 fee to become registered supporters and eligible to vote in the leadership election .
the challenger 's hopes of unseating mr corbyn rest on winning over this group .
however , mr smith is attracting only one in four , with 70 per cent opting for mr corbyn and the rest undecided .
the remaining 168,000 voters are union affiliates and mr corbyn is in the lead among this group , on 54 per cent against mr smith 's 33 per cent .
i will post more from the poll soon .
later i will be focusing on the tories .
as anushka asthana and rowena mason report , the cabinet is meeting at chequers this morning , for the first time since july , to discuss brexit .
it is not clear how much we will learn afterwards , but i will be covering everything that emerges .
as usual , i will be covering the breaking political news as it happens , as well as bringing you the best reaction , comment and analysis from the web .
i will post a summary at lunchtime and another in the afternoon .
if you want to follow me or contact me on twitter , i 'm @ twitterid .
i try to monitor the comments btl but normally i find it impossible to read them all .
if you have a direct question , do include andrew '' in it somewhere and i 'm more likely to find it .
i do try to answer direct questions , although sometimes i miss them or do n't have time .
alternatively you could post a question to me on twitter .

key_events.text:
